t: Luke 14
A Sabbath Controversy
One*p Sabbath, when he went in to eat at the house of one of the leading Pharisees, they were watching him closely.
There in front of him was a man whose body was swollen with fluid.
In response, Jesus asked the law experts and the Pharisees, “Is*r it*r lawful*r to*r heal*r on*r the*r Sabbath*r or*r not?”*r
But they kept silent. He took the man, healed him, and sent him away.
And to them, he said, “Which*r of*r you*r whose*r son*r or*r ox*r falls*r into*r a*r well,*r will*r not*r immediately*r pull*r him*r out*r on*r the*r Sabbath*r day?”*r
They could find no answer to these things.
Teachings on Humility
He*p told a parable to those who were invited, when he noticed how they would choose the best places for themselves:

“When*r you*r are*r invited*r by*r someone*r to*r a*r wedding*r banquet,*r don’t*r sit*r in*r the*r place*r of*r honor,*r because*r a*r more*r distinguished*r person*r than*r you*r may*r have*r been*r invited*r by*r your*r host.*r

The*r one*r who*r invited*r both*r of*r you*r may*r come*r and*r say*r to*r you,*r ‘Give*r your*r place*r to*r this*r man,’*r and*r then*r in*r humiliation,*r you*r will*r proceed*r to*r take*r the*r lowest*r place.*r

“But*rp when*r you*r are*r invited,*r go*r and*r sit*r in*r the*r lowest*r place,*r so*r that*r when*r the*r one*r who*r invited*r you*r comes,*r he*r will*r say*r to*r you,*r ‘Friend,*r move*r up*r higher.’*r You*r will*r then*r be*r honored*r in*r the*r presence*r of*r all*r the*r other*r guests.*r
For*r everyone*r who*r exalts*r himself*r will*r be*r humbled,*r and*r the*r one*r who*r humbles*r himself*r will*r be*r exalted.”*r

He*p also said to the one who had invited him, “When*r you*r give*r a*r lunch*r or*r a*r dinner,*r don’t*r invite*r your*r friends,*r your*r brothers*r or*r sisters,*r your*r relatives,*r or*r your*r rich*r neighbors,*r because*r they*r might*r invite*r you*r back,*r and*r you*r would*r be*r repaid.*r
On*r the*r contrary,*r when*r you*r host*r a*r banquet,*r invite*r those*r who*r are*r poor,*r maimed,*r lame,*r or*r blind.*r
And*r you*r will*r be*r blessed,*r because*r they*r cannot*r repay*r you;*r for*r you*r will*r be*r repaid*r at*r the*r resurrection*r of*r the*r righteous.”*r
The Parable of the Large Banquet
When*p one of those who reclined at the table with him heard these things, he said to him, “Blessed is the one who will eat bread in the kingdom of God!”
Then*p he told him, “A*r man*r was*r giving*r a*r large*r banquet*r and*r invited*r many.*r
At*r the*r time*r of*r the*r banquet,*r he*r sent*r his*r servant*r to*r tell*r those*r who*r were*r invited,*r ‘Come,*r because*r everything*r is*r now*r ready.’*r

“But*rp without*r exception*r they*r all*r began*r to*r make*r excuses.*r The*r first*r one*r said*r to*r him,*r ‘I*r have*r bought*r a*r field,*r and*r I*r must*r go*r out*r and*r see*r it.*r I*r ask*r you*r to*r excuse*r me.’*r
“Another*rp said,*r ‘I*r have*r bought*r five*r yoke*r of*r oxen,*r and*r I’m*r going*r to*r try*r them*r out.*r I*r ask*r you*r to*r excuse*r me.’*r
“And*rp another*r said,*r ‘I*r just*r got*r married,*r and*r therefore*r I’m*r unable*r to*r come.’*r

“So*rp the*r servant*r came*r back*r and*r reported*r these*r things*r to*r his*r master.*r Then*r in*r anger,*r the*r master*r of*r the*r house*r told*r his*r servant,*r ‘Go*r out*r quickly*r into*r the*r streets*r and*r alleys*r of*r the*r city,*r and*r bring*r in*r here*r the*r poor,*r maimed,*r blind,*r and*r lame.’*r
“‘Master,’*rp the*r servant*r said,*r ‘what*r you*r ordered*r has*r been*r done,*r and*r there’s*r still*r room.’*r
“Then*rp the*r master*r told*r the*r servant,*r ‘Go*r out*r into*r the*r highways*r and*r hedges*r and*r make*r them*r come*r in,*r so*r that*r my*r house*r may*r be*r filled.*r
For*r I*r tell*r you,*r not*r one*r of*r those*r people*r who*r were*r invited*r will*r enjoy*r my*r banquet.’”*r
The Cost of Following Jesus
Now*p great crowds were traveling with him. So he turned and said to them,

“If*r anyone*r comes*r to*r me*r and*r does*r not*r hate*r his*r own*r father*r and*r mother,*r wife*r and*r children,*r brothers*r and*r sisters -*r yes,*r and*r even*r his*r own*r life -*r he*r cannot*r be*r my*r disciple.*r
Whoever*r does*r not*r bear*r his*r own*r cross*r and*r come*r after*r me*r cannot*r be*r my*r disciple.*r
“For*rp which*r of*r you,*r wanting*r to*r build*r a*r tower,*r doesn’t*r first*r sit*r down*r and*r calculate*r the*r cost*r to*r see*r if*r he*r has*r enough*r to*r complete*r it?*r
Otherwise,*r after*r he*r has*r laid*r the*r foundation*r and*r cannot*r finish*r it,*r all*r the*r onlookers*r will*r begin*r to*r ridicule*r him,*r
saying,*r ‘This*r man*r started*r to*r build*r and*r wasn’t*r able*r to*r finish.’*r

“Or*rp what*r king,*r going*r to*r war*r against*r another*r king,*r will*r not*r first*r sit*r down*r and*r decide*r if*r he*r is*r able*r with*r ten*r thousand*r to*r oppose*r the*r one*r who*r comes*r against*r him*r with*r twenty*r thousand?*r
If*r not,*r while*r the*r other*r is*r still*r far*r off,*r he*r sends*r a*r delegation*r and*r asks*r for*r terms*r of*r peace.*r
In*r the*r same*r way,*r therefore,*r every*r one*r of*r you*r who*r does*r not*r renounce*r all*r his*r possessions*r cannot*r be*r my*r disciple.*r
“Now,*rp salt*r is*r good,*r but*r if*r salt*r should*r lose*r its*r taste,*r how*r will*r it*r be*r made*r salty?*r
It*r isn’t*r fit*r for*r the*r soil*r or*r for*r the*r manure*r pile;*r they*r throw*r it*r out.*r Let*r anyone*r who*r has*r ears*r to*r hear*r listen.”*r
